text:
Prince Harry and Meghan Markle welcomed at Government House

Even seasoned royal correspondents have been left exhausted and in awe of Meghan’s work ethic, despite a number pitfalls including warnings against travelling while pregnant. Writing for Australian news website, Honey, an exhausted Juliet Rieden told of how this tour has seen the royal couple gain an international seal of approval, while sending “ her circadian rhythms into meltdown.” She said: “As a seasoned royal correspondent, I like to think I’m well versed in the madness and mayhem of royal tours but this inaugural Commonwealth love-in with the Duke and Duchess of Sussex had surprises at every turn and a pace that has sent my circadian rhythms into meltdown. “It started with a baby announcement that blind-sided us all. While the tabloids have been on bump watch since the couple announced their engagement, no-one really believed that Meghan would embark on a 16-day marathon tour with 76 engagements while pregnant. Even the UK royal watchers weren’t in on this secret, which is saying something. “Of course ‘pregnant women works’, is not the stuff of headlines, this is 2018 after all. But the royal couple weren’t just touring Australia and New Zealand; Fiji and Tonga were an important part of the itinerary, nations beloved by Her Majesty who were aching for a royal visit, especially one from the House of Windsor’s new super couple.”

Meghan Markle and Prince Harry kickstarted their first royal tour as a married couple, landing in Sydney, Australia on Tuesday, October 16. But the determined duchess began the trip as she meant to go on, attending an engagement despite suffering from the "double whammy" of jet lag and pregnancy. She’d woke up at 4.30am to do some yoga, telling a group at Bondi beach that yoga was "so good for healing your mind". Days later the crowd went wild for the duchess as Harry and Meghan received a joyous welcome at the delayed Opening Ceremony of the fourth ever Invictus Games. The pair still beamed with joy despite an electrical storm sparking chaos in Sydney earlier the same day.

The Duchess of Sussex smiles during a visit to Tupou College

Harry and Meghan on Bondi Beach in Australia

Meghan Markle and Prince Harry arrive in New Zealand

SUBSCRIBE Invalid email We use your sign-up to provide content in ways you've consented to and to improve our understanding of you. This may include adverts from us and 3rd parties based on our understanding. You can unsubscribe at any time. More info

But as Meghan started to flag and skipped some of the pair’s planned engagements, so questions were raised as to whether the duchess would be able to visit Fiji and Tonga at all - with World Health Organisation advises against pregnant women travelling to those countries due to the Zika virus. After Harry faced a bumpy ride to Fraser Island to unveil a plaque alone, royal fans were certain that the duchess would pull out on a visit to Fiji altogether. But Ms Rieden praised Meghan for proving spectators wrong and going ahead with an “incredible trip” to Fiji and seemingly being “totally unfazed by the mozzies”. The royal pair joined an exhibition with Princess Angelika of Tonga on the 11th day of the tour, who called the couple “an inspiration to the youth of the Commonwealth” for “shining a light on youth empowerment”.

The Duchess of Sussex congratulating the United States Wheelchair Basketball team after winning Gold

The couple at Consular House in Tonga on the first day of their visit to the country

Meghan greets a young girl in Fiji
title: Meghan Markle wins over Royal fans on her first tour

og.title: Meghan's royal tour SUCCESS: How Duchess won over royal fans
og.description:
MEGHAN Markle has won over Royal fans during her whirlwind first tour packed full of “surprises at every turn”, according to an Australian royal expert.
With 76 engagements starting kicking off with the “blind-siding” announcement of the Duchess’ pregnancy, this had been a Royal tour like no other.
